news.headlineText: Cisco discloses appointment of Maria Martinez as COO
news.story: On March 4, the Board of Directors of Cisco Systems appointed Maria Martinez as COO of Cisco. Ms. Martinez joined Cisco in April 2018 as EVP and Chief Customer Experience Officer, and in December 2020, Ms. Martinez took on an expanded role to lead certain operations functions in addition to customer experience as one, united team, including supply chain, IT, security and trust, data and analytics, customer and partner services, and strategy and business acceleration.

news.headlineText: Closing Stock Market Summary
news.story:
The S&P 500 advanced 2.0% on Friday in a resilient session that featured better-than-expected payrolls growth for February. The benchmark index was down as much as 1.0% intraday as investors sold into early strength, but others stepped in to buy the dip and propel the market to session highs by the close.

The Nasdaq Composite gained 1.6% after being down 2.6% intraday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.9% after being down 0.5% intraday, and the Russell 2000 gained 2.1% after being down 2.9% intraday.

The February employment report showcased nonfarm payrolls increase by 379,000 (Briefing.com consensus 200,000), which the market viewed as a bullish sign for future economic growth, as the labor market recovery appeared to pick up steam ahead of increased reopening/vaccination efforts. The unemployment rate was 6.2% (Briefing.com consensus 6.3%), versus 6.3% in January.

The 10-yr yield briefly matched last week's high of 1.61% following the data, before settling unchanged at 1.55%. Interestingly, the rise in yields didn't deter risk sentiment as every sector in the S&P 500 started the session in positive territory. Instead, the negative price action that followed fueled concerns that the recent correction in the heavily-weighted growth stocks wasn't over.

Nearly every sector turned negative, with the exceptions being energy (+3.9%) and consumer staples (+2.2%). Shares of Tesla (TSLA 597.95, -23.49, -3.8%) were down more than 13.0% at one point. Selling abated around the close of European markets at 11:30 a.m. ET amid a sense that selling had gotten overdone on a short-term basis.

Energy stocks built on their outperformance, as oil prices ($66.09, +2.26, +3.5%) rallied above $66 per barrel, and every other sector caught the wave of buying interest. The consumer discretionary sector (+0.7%) was the only sector that increased less than 1.0% due to Tesla's decline.

Note, while the S&P 500 never went below yesterday's intraday low, the Nasdaq and Russell 2000 did. The S&P 500 managed to close back above its 50-day moving average (3822) after closing below it on Thursday.

Shares of Cisco (CSCO 46.25, +1.69, +3.8%) and Oracle (ORCL 69.93, +4.32, +6.6%) outperformed following a pair of analyst upgrades. JP Morgan upgraded CSCO to Overweight from Neutral. Barclays upgraded ORCL to Overweight from Equal Weight.

The 2-yr yield increased one basis point to 0.15%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.4% to 91.96.

Reviewing Friday's economic data:

  • The February Employment Situation Report was much better than expected on the payrolls front. The payrolls increase is the highlight of the report and is apt to be the lead headline when it comes to talking about the report; however, there is a soft underbelly to the report that should not go unnoticed. The labor force participation rate was unchanged at 61.4% (down from 63.3% a year ago), the U-6 unemployment rate is still high at 11.1%, and persons unemployed for 27 weeks or more accounted for 41.5% of the unemployed versus 39.5% in January. The pace of hiring might have picked up in February, yet the travails of the long-term unemployed did as well.
    • The key takeaway from the report is that it will be seen as a sign of even better things to come for the labor market, which bodes well for growth prospects. The increase in nonfarm payrolls was the strongest since October and the best pace for February in more than 20 years, which is encouraging in that it came in front of more states seemingly destined to relax Covid restrictions in coming months as vaccination rates improve.
  • The January trade deficit widened to -$68.2 billion (Briefing.com consensus -$67.5 billion) from a downwardly revised -$67.0 billion (from -$66.6 billion) in December. The widening in the deficit was a byproduct of exports increasing less than imports.
    • The key takeaway from the report is that trade activity will be imputed as a drag on Q1 GDP growth for now as the real trade deficit in January was 2.4% more than the fourth quarter average.
  • Consumer credit decreased by $1.3 bln in January after increasing a downwardly revised $8.8 bln (from $9.7 bln) in December.
    • The key takeaway from the report is that revolving credit decreased for the tenth time over the last 11 months dating back to February, which preceded the initial pandemic lockdown period taking hold in the U.S.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Wholesale Inventories for January on Monday.

  • Russell 2000 +11.0% YTD
  • Dow Jones Industrial Average +2.9% YTD
  • S&P 500 +2.3% YTD
  • Nasdaq Composite +0.3% YTD

news.headlineText: Canada - March 3
news.story:
March 3 (Reuters) - The following are the top stories from selected Canadian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.





THE GLOBE AND MAIL

• Sky Regional Airlines Inc will shut down its commercial flight operations on March 31 after losing its Air Canada Express contract, becoming the first mid-sized Canadian airline to fall victim to the pandemic.



• Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp to get new chief executive officer as Evan Siddall steps down next month.



• Super Channel has asked Alberta's superior court to block the sale of digital set-top boxes that it alleges are being used to steal its programming.

NATIONAL POST

• The federal government in recent years has awarded internal contracts to technology company Cisco Systems with high frequency, part of what some observers call a pattern of dependency by Ottawa on a single network provider that has all but shut out competing bids.



(Compiled by Bengaluru newsroom) ((globalnewsmonitoring@thomsonreuters.com))

news.headlineText: Sector Briefing: Technology
news.story:
The top-weighted technology sector (-1.1%) started today's session behind the remaining ten groups after a strong showing yesterday. The opening loss has narrowed the group's week-to-date gain to 2.0%.

Key factors driving today's performance include:

  • Soft showing from the largest components of the sector. Apple (AAPL 126.36, -1.43, -1.1%), Microsoft (MSFT 234.15, -2.79, -1.2%), Visa (V 215.32, -1.31, -0.6%), and NVIDIA (NVDA 550.07, -3.60, -0.7%) stumbled out of the gate, weighing on the broader sector.
  • Broad-based weakness among high-beta chipmakers. The PHLX Semiconductor Index is down 1.4%, trimming its week-to-date gain to 1.8%.

Notable movers:

  • Cadence Design (CDNS 141.98, -5.46, -3.7%): weakest performer in the sector, surrendering yesterday's gain after finding resistance near its record high.
  • KLA Corporation (KLAC 315.88, -10.11, -3.1%): surrendering yesterday's gain.
  • Teradyne (TER 130.66, -3.34, -2.4%): falling toward its 50-day moving average (129.03).
  • Citrix Systems (CTXS 135.37, -3.28, -2.4%): falling back below its 200-day moving average (135.85).
  • Broadcom (AVGO 482.43, -7.15, -1.5%): slipping toward yesterday's low after Cowen raised its target for the stock to $470 from $415.
  • Applied Materials (AMAT 120.65, -1.60, -1.3%): approaching yesterday's low.
  • PayPal (PYPL 270.16, -3.47, -1.3%): dipping from a one-week high.
  • Microsoft (MSFT 234.15, -2.79, -1.2%): slipping toward yesterday's low.
  • Apple (AAPL 126.36, -1.43, -1.1%): backtracking from a one-week high.
  • Cisco (CSCO 45.56, -0.36, -0.8%): slipping back below its 50-day moving average (45.57).
  • Fortinet (FTNT 172.00, -1.26, -0.7%): touched a fresh record high before turning negative.
  • NVIDIA (NVDA 550.07, -3.60, -0.7%): slipping back to its 50-day moving average (546.07).
  • FleetCor (FLT 285.29, +2.79, +1.0%): best performer in the sector.

news.headlineText: Shares of several technology companies are trading higher as yields pull back, which has helped lift growth sectors. Stocks across sectors also gain amid COVID-19 vaccine optimism and stimulus progress.
Acacia Communications announces completion of acquisition by Cisco (CSCO) (halted)
news.story: Cisco has agreed to acquire Acacia for $115.00/share in cash, or approx. $4.5 bln on a fully diluted basis, net of cash and marketable securities. As a result of the transaction, Acacia is no longer a publicly traded company. Acacia has notified NASDAQ of the completion of the acquisition and has requested that NASDAQ file a notification of delisting with the SEC on Acacia's behalf.

news.headlineText: Italy - Factors to watch on Feb. 16
news.story:
The following factors could affect Italian markets on Tuesday.

Reuters has not verified the newspaper reports, and cannot vouch for their accuracy. New items are marked with (•).



For a complete list of diary events in Italy please click on .



GENERAL

Italy reported 258 coronavirus-related deaths on Monday against 221 the day before, the health ministry said, while the daily tally of new infections fell to 7,351 from 11,068 the day before.



ECONOMY

ISTAT releases December foreign trade data (0900 GMT).



COMPANIES

CREVAL

Italy has given a green light to the takeover bid Credit Agricole Italia plans to make for the small rival, the French bank's Italian arm said on Monday, after two sources had anticipated the news to Reuters.

DWS Investments cut its stake in the Italian lender to 2.976% from 5.461%, while Petrus Adivsers held a 3.015% stake, according to a regulatory filing.



STELLANTIS

The carmaker has extended until Tuesday a production freeze at its Melfi plant in southern Italy, citing persistent shortages of semiconductors.



MEDIASET

The Italian broadcaster does not intend to acquire additional voting rights in ProSiebenSat.1 Media in the next 12 months or to exercise influence on the appointment of management, according to a regulatory announcement on Monday.



A2A

An administrative court has cancelled a decision of Seregno city Council which paved the way to the merger between Italy's largest regional utility and smaller local rival AEB, three different rulings seen by Reuters said on Monday.



SAIPEM

Marathon Asset Management held a 5.102% stake in the Italian energy services group as of Feb. 9, a regulatory filing said.



POSTE ITALIANE

Board meeting on preliminary FY results, press release on Feb. 17.





DIARY

Rome, Hoist Finance Spa CEO Clemente Reale speaks before Banking Committee on the business models of operators working in NPL and UTP markets (1215 GMT).

Milan, celebration for the first year of the Cybersecurity Co-Innovation Center with Italy's cybersecurity department Vice Director General Roberto Baldoni, H-Farm Chairman Riccardo Donadon, Cisco Chairman and CEO Chuck Robbins (1500 GMT).





((Milan newsroom, +39 02 6612 9507, fax +39 02 801149, milan.newsroom@news.reuters.com))

news.headlineText: Closing Stock Market Summary
news.story:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.2%) eked out a closing record high on Wednesday, while the S&P 500 (-0.03%), Nasdaq Composite (-0.3%), and Russell 2000 (-0.7%) closed lower after setting intraday record highs early in the session.

The market's highs came shortly after the open, as investors remained confident in the growth prospects of the economy, but the market quickly descended into negative territory amid a sense that stock prices had increased too much, too fast. The S&P 500 went from a 0.5% intraday gain to a 0.7% intraday decline in about 45 minutes.

Price action stabilized, and the benchmark index wavered around its flat line for the rest of the session. The energy (+1.8%), communication services (+0.6%), and real estate (+0.6%) sectors advanced the most today, while the consumer discretionary sector (-0.9%) underperformed amid profit-taking weakness in Tesla (TSLA 804.82, -44.64, -5.3%).

In the afternoon, Fed Chair Powell reiterated in a speech that interest rates will remain near zero until the Fed achieves its dual mandate of maximum employment and a 2.0%+ inflation rate over time. Mr. Powell added that the central bank will maintain its $120 billion in asset purchases per month.

On a related note, total CPI was up 0.3% m/m in January (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%), and Core CPI, which excludes food and energy, was unchanged (Briefing.com consensus 0.2%). Core CPI decelerated to 1.4% from 1.6% in December. While the CPI data isn't the Fed's preferred inflation gauge, it still signaled muted inflation pressure for consumers.

The 10-yr Treasury note yield decreased two basis points to 1.13% after trading at 1.17% prior to the data. The 2-yr yield decreased two basis points to 0.10%. The U.S. Dollar Index finished little changed at 90.43. WTI crude futures increased 0.6%, or $0.36, to $58.71/bbl.

Separately, Coca-Cola (KO 49.60, -0.10, -0.2%), Cisco (CSCO 47.24, -1.26, -2.6%), and General Motors (GM 54.88, -1.18, -2.1%) closed lower despite beating earnings estimates, while Twitter (TWTR 67.77, +7.90, +13.2%) and Lyft (LYFT 56.21, +2.57, +4.8%) pleased investors with their results and commentary.

Reviewing Wednesday's economic data:

  • Total CPI for January was up 0.3% m/m (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) following a downwardly revised 0.2% increase (from 0.4%) in December. Core CPI, which excludes food and energy, was unchanged (Briefing.com consensus 0.2%) after also being revised to unchanged (from 0.1%) in December. On a year-over-year basis, total CPI held steady at 1.4%, yet core CPI decelerated to 1.4% from 1.6% in December.
    • The key takeaway from the report is that it shows all is still mostly quiet on the inflation front as far as the Fed is concerned, which implies to the market that it can continue to count on the Fed not to run interference with its rally effort by raising rates or tapering its bond purchases prematurely.
  • Wholesale inventories increased 0.3 m/m in December (Briefing.com consensus +0.1%) following a revised 0.1% increase in November (from 0.0%).
  • The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index decreased 4.1% following an 8.1% increase in the prior week.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the weekly Initial and Continuing Claims report on Thursday.

  • Russell 2000 +15.6% YTD
  • Nasdaq Composite +8.4% YTD
  • S&P 500 +4.1% YTD
  • Dow Jones Industrial Average +2.7% YTD

news.headlineText: Market Briefing: Market rolls on, then rolls over
news.story:
The stock market got off to a good start, but the good times didn't keep rolling. Rather, the good returns rolled over on a pickup in selling interest that didn't have a discernible catalyst.

The latter understanding was the notable driver as it prompted some broader selling interest on the basis that this is a sign of a market that recognizes it has come a long way in a short time and will find further gains tougher to come by in the near term.

The information technology sector (-0.5%) and some mega-cap stocks, like Amazon.com (AMZN 3280.00, -25.00, -0.8%), Tesla (TSLA 813.82, -35.64, -4.2%), and Apple (AAPL 135.44, -0.57, -0.4%), have been weighty influences on the major indices.

Other laggards of note include General Motors (GM 53.64, -2.42, -4.3%) and Cisco (CSCO 46.32, -2.18, -4.5%) following their respective earnings reports and commentary. Conversely, Lyft (LYFT 56.08, +2.44, +4.6%) and Twitter (TWTR 65.04, +5.17, +8.6%) have been greeted favorably by investors following their respective reports and commentary.

Also notable today is that the stock market is languishing even though Fed Chair Powell is expected to reiterate his call for extended policy support when he speaks at 2:00 p.m. ET today about the state of the labor market. Additionally, a drop in long-term rates following a friendly CPI report for January hasn't been much of a support factor either. The 10-yr yield is down two basis points to 1.14%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 0.1%; the S&P 500 is down 0.1%; the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.5%; and the Russell 2000 is down 1.4%.

news.headlineText: Cisco slumps lower despite good earnings results
news.story:
Cisco Systems (CSCO -5%) is trading a good bit lower today even after the company issued an upside earnings report, solid guidance, and a modest dividend increase. However, the report also included a few trouble spots.

Why is the stock lower despite what looks like generally good results?

  • Adjusted EPS and revenue for Q2 (Jan) both exceeded estimates. Maybe we are nitpicking, but the $0.04 EPS upside was a notch lower than the $0.06-0.08 beats Cisco posted in the prior three quarters.
  • The guidance for Q3 (Apr) may be weighing on the stock a bit. After guiding nicely higher last quarter, Cisco is guiding EPS in-line this quarter. However, revenue guidance had some modest upside; if Cisco were to hit its target, AprQ would mark a return to yr/yr growth for the first time in several quarters.
  • Margins are a closely watched metric with Cisco, and the company performed well here despite a difficult macro environment. Non-GAAP operating margin in Q2 was 34.4% vs prior guidance of 32-33%. However, Cisco is guiding to a sequential decline in margins in Q3 at 33-34%, although it is possible that Cisco is guiding conservatively.
  • The earnings call was mixed. Cisco said it's seeing signs of gradual improvement led by order growth in Commercial, Public Sector, and Service Provider businesses. However, the Enterprise market remains soft, driven by some elongated sales cycles and a continued pause in spending among some customers in connection with the pandemic. Investors keep hoping to see Enterprise start to turn the corner, but it sounds like it will take time.
  • Infrastructure Platforms was down 3%. As a reminder, this is the product area most impacted by the COVID environment. That's a notable improvement from down 16% in Q1, but it's still a problem area for Cisco.

There were some rays of hope. Total product revenue was down 1% yr/yr to $8.6 bln, an improvement from down 13% last quarter. Switching revenue was flat overall, and Cisco saw solid growth in Data Center Switching, including strong growth for the Nexus 9000. Wireless growth was driven by the continued ramp of Wi-Fi 6 products. Webex remains a bright spot, reporting double-digit growth fueled by remote working. Security was up 10%, with cloud security seeing strong double-digit growth.

In sum, this was really more of a mixed quarter overall. After last quarter's strong results/guidance, this quarter's numbers were not quite as robust. Cisco is cautiously optimistic for IT budget growth in calendar 2021, but the recovery is going to take some time for Cisco. While the company has cloud, security, and video conferencing segments, which are the hot areas for remote working, Cisco remains heavily exposed to large hardware components and enterprise, which have been laggards.

news.headlineText: Earnings/guidance movers
Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins CNBC interview
news.story:
Mr. Robbins said:

  • Every customer segment improved.
  • WiFi demand was up 20% yr/yr.
  • Other products had double digit growth.
  • Customers are realizing that security and privacy are important in data products.

  • SPCE -1.5% (downgraded to Neutral from Buy at UBS)
  • CHUY -1.2% (downgraded to Mkt Perform from Outperform at Raymond James)

news.headlineText: Early premarket gappers
After Hours Summary: USNA +15.4%, MODN +13.2%, LYFT +10.5% higher on earnings; AYX -8.8%, AKAM -7%, CSCO -5.4% lower on earnings
news.story:
After Hours Gainers:

Companies trading higher in after hours in reaction to earnings/guidance: USNA +15.4% (also authorizes $150 mln share repurchase program), MODN +13.2%, LYFT +10.5%, CCK +7.8%, OI +6.4%, ENPH +5.9%, URBN +5.9%, RICK +5.8%, STEP +4.6%, THC +3.8%, QGEN +3.6%, MESA +3.5%, GPRE +3.2%, TWTR +2.6%, MAT +2.3%, TWO +2.3%, BW +2.3% (also announces stock offering), RPD +2%, YELP +2%, BKH +0.1%, PRI +0.1% (also raises dividend; approves new buyback),

Companies trading higher in after hours in reaction to news: GNFT +103.8% (positive results from the Ph 2 clinical trial evaluating elafibranor), GMDA +71.6% (presents Phase 3 data on omidubicel; anticipates BLA submission in 2H21), KALV +3.3% (stock offering), MTCH +2.4% (to acquire Hyperconnect for US$1.725 bln in cash and stock), FULT +1.7% (approves $75 mln stock repurchase program), IVZ +1.4% (reports Jan AUM data), KTOS +1.1% (stock offering), WYNN +0.9% (WynnBET receives conditional approval for online sports betting in Tennessee), MRNA +0.7% (announces vaccine supply agreements with Taiwan and Colombia), SRG +0.2% (new CEO), IBM +0.2% (Instacart acquires over 250 patents from IBM), APAM +0.1% (reports Jan AUM data), SQZ +0.1% (stock offering),

After Hours Losers:

Companies trading lower in after hours in reaction to earnings/guidance: CPSI -13.4%, AYX -8.8%, ATEN -8.7%, AKAM -7% (also announces organizational changes), PAA -7%, CDAY -6.9%, CSCO -5.4% (also raises dividend), NCR -4%, NGL -3.6%, FMC -3%, DCPH -2.7%, VOYA -2.6%, MTW -2.5%, FISV -1.7%, EXTR -1.4%, WELL -0.9%, REYN -0.8% (also raises dividend), G -0.3% (also announces $500 mln increase to share repurchase auth; and 10% dividend increase), DEI -0.2%, HIW -0.2%,

Companies trading lower in after hours in reaction to news: VNRX -12% (stock offering), XONE -9.2% (stock offering), ENLV -8.7% (announces $10 mln bought deal offering), LMB -7.9% (stock offering), BLDP -6.4% (announces $350 mln bought deal offering), CDAK -4% (stock offering), MREO -2.3% (ADS offering), ONCR -2.2% (stock offering), SNY -0.6% (FDA approves Libtayo as immunotherapy for patients with advanced basal cell carcinoma), VRNS -0.3% (files for mixed securities shelf offering),

news.headlineText: Cisco On Call
news.story:
• Enterprise still soft
  • Saw gradual recovery in several products
  • Switching revs were flat overall
  • Routing declined driven by weakness in service provider

news.headlineText: Cisco Reports Q2 EPS $0.60
news.story:
Feb 9 (Reuters) - Cisco Systems Inc :

• CISCO REPORTS SECOND QUARTER EARNINGS

• Q2 REVENUE $12 BILLION VERSUS REFINITIV IBES ESTIMATE OF $11.92 BILLION

• SEES Q3 GAAP EARNINGS PER SHARE $0.64 TO $0.69

• CISCO - QTRLY EARNINGS PER SHARE $0.60

• Q2 EARNINGS PER SHARE VIEW $0.76 -- REFINITIV IBES DATA

• CISCO - RECOGNIZED $602 MILLION AND $232 MILLION OF RESTRUCTURING CHARGES DURING FIRST AND Q2 OF FISCAL 2021 Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage: ((Reuters.Briefs@thomsonreuters.com;))

news.headlineText: Notable earnings/guidance movers: ENPH +8.8%, LYFT +6%, YELP +4.6% on the upside; AKAM -6.9%, AYX -5.2%, CSCO -3.1%, NCR -2.3%, FISV -2.2% on the downside
news.story:
• Earnings/guidance gainers: ENPH +8.8%, LYFT +6%, YELP +4.6%, THC +3.8%, TWO +2.5%, MESA +2.4%, QGEN +1.7%, REYN +1.7%, TWTR +1.6%
  • Earnings/guidance losers: AKAM -6.9%, AYX -5.2%, CSCO -3.1%, NCR -2.3%, FISV -2.2%

news.headlineText: Cisco forecasts third-quarter sales above estimates on remote work boost
news.story:
(Adds forecast, unit details)

Feb 9 (Reuters) - Cisco Systems Inc forecast current-quarter revenue above analysts' estimates on Tuesday as the pandemic-induced rise in remote working drives up demand for its networking and teleconferencing tools.

With offices staying shut and scores of professionals working from home due to the health crisis, demand for the company's videoconferencing platform Webex, virtual private network AnyConnect and cybersecurity products has surged.

Cisco said it expects third-quarter revenue to increase between 3.5% to 5.5%, which implies a range between $12.4 billion to $12.64 billion compared with analysts' estimate of $12.35 billion.

The company's revenue from the services business rose 2% to $3.39 billion in the second quarter ended Jan. 23.

However, total revenue fell slightly to $11.96 billion, from $12.01 billion a year earlier. Analysts were expecting a figure of $11.92 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. (Reporting by Munsif Vengattil in Bengaluru; Editing by Aditya Soni) ((munsif.vengattil@thomsonreuters.com;))

news.headlineText: Cisco beats by $0.04, reports revs in-line; guides AprQ EPS in-line, revs above consensus; increases quarterly dividend by 3%
news.story:
• Reports Q2 (Jan) earnings of $0.79 per share, excluding non-recurring items, $0.04 better than the S&P Capital IQ Consensus of $0.75; revenues fell 0.4% year/year to $11.96 bln vs the $11.90 bln S&P Capital IQ Consensus.
    • Non-GAAP operating margin was 34.4%, above prior guidance of 32-33%.
    • Product revenue strength across Catalyst 9000, Data Center Switching, Security, Wireless and Webex portfolios.
    • Great progress on business transformation to more software and subscription, with 76% of software revenue sold as a subscription.
  • Co issues guidance for Q3 (Apr), sees EPS of $0.80-0.82, excluding non-recurring items, vs. $0.81 S&P Capital IQ Consensus; sees Q3 revs of $12.40-12.64 bln vs. $12.32 bln S&P Capital IQ Consensus.
  • "We are seeing encouraging signs of strength across our business showing how our technology will be a powerful engine for recovery and growth...Cisco executed well in Q2, delivering growth in orders, strong margins, and growth in non-GAAP EPS, while continuing to grow deferred revenue in double-digits through the shift to more software and subscriptions."
  • Co increases quarterly dividend by 3% to $0.37/sh from $0.36/sh.

news.headlineText: Cisco Systems shares are trading lower after the company reported Q2 earnings results and issued Q3 guidance.
Cisco beats quarterly revenue estimates
news.story:
Feb 9 (Reuters) - Cisco Systems Inc on Tuesday beat quarterly revenue estimates, helped by robust demand for its networking and teleconferencing tools due to the pandemic-induced rise in remote working.

The company's revenue fell slightly to $11.96 billion in the second quarter ended Jan. 23, from $12.01 billion a year earlier. Analysts on average were expecting a figure of $11.92 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. (Reporting by Munsif Vengattil in Bengaluru; Editing by Aditya Soni) ((munsif.vengattil@thomsonreuters.com;))

news.headlineText: Cisco sees Q3 $0.80-0.82 vs $0.81 S&P Capital IQ Consensus Estimate; sees revs $12.40-12.64 bln vs $12.32 bln S&P Capital IQ Consensus Estimate
Cisco prelim Q2 $0.79 vs $0.75 S&P Capital IQ Consensus Estimate; revs $11.96 bln vs $11.90 bln S&P Capital IQ Consensus Estimate
Cisco: Earnings Preview; tends to report upside
news.story:
Cisco Systems (CSCO) is set to report Q2 (Jan) results today after the close with a call to follow at 4:30pm ET. CSCO typically reports 5 minutes after the close. The current S&P CapitalIQ consensus is for adjusted EPS of $0.75 (down 3% yr/yr) and revenue of $11.90 bln (down 1% yr/yr). Cisco typically guides for EPS and revenue (on a percentage basis) for the next quarter.

  • Last quarter, Cisco guided to Q2 adjusted EPS of $0.74-0.76 and to revenue of $11.77-12.01 bln. Cisco tends to be conservative with guidance, which usually translates into analysts being on the higher end of guidance. But this time consensus is pretty smack dab in the middle which may mean analysts are a bit less confident. Current guidance for non-GAAP operating margin in Q2 is 32-33%. Non-GAAP operating margin in Q1 was 32.7% vs prior guidance of 30-31%.
  • Revenue declined in FY20 (Jul) and is expected to decline again in FY21 before returning to growth in FY22. The big problem is on the hardware side as Cisco's core switching and routing sales (Infrastructure Platforms), which represent roughly 40% of total sales, have been on the decline. Cisco has been moving more into software and services, but hardware remains a big piece.
  • Cisco is a particularly important tech name to watch with earnings. Because it's so large and touches so many areas, it's a great barometer to get a general sense for enterprise sending levels on IT. It's also the first big tech name to report that includes the month of January, so we should get a better sense of how briskly enterprises are spending this winter season with COVID cases rising again.
  • Cisco has been active on the M&A front, announcing recent deals to acquire Acacia Communications (ACIA) for $4.5 bln and IMImobile for $730 mln. Acacia makes optical interconnect products that are used by cloud infrastructure operators, with a focus on embedded and pluggable modules. Pluggable modules is a high growth area and it's still in the early stages. The industry is transitioning from chassis-based systems to pluggable technology to simplify operations.
  • Finally, in terms of what to expect, Cisco has not missed on EPS in the past five years, so it's pretty reliable. Of note, the beats have been getting larger since the pandemic again, in the $0.06-0.08 range, following a series of smaller $0.01-0.03 beats. (PVIEW)

news.headlineText: Cisco: Earnings Preview; tends to report upside but is not usually a big mover around earnings
news.story:
Cisco Systems (CSCO) is set to report Q2 (Jan) results today after the close with a call to follow at 4:30pm ET. CSCO typically reports 5 minutes after the close. The current S&P CapitalIQ consensus is for adjusted EPS of $0.75 (down 3% yr/yr) and revenue of $11.90 bln (down 1% yr/yr). Cisco tends to be conservative with guidance, which usually translates into analysts being on the higher end of guidance. But this time consensus is pretty smack dab in the middle which may mean analysts are a bit less confident. Current guidance for non-GAAP operating margin in Q2 is 32-33%. Non-GAAP operating margin in Q1 was 32.7% vs prior guidance of 30-31%.

The big problem is on the hardware side as Cisco's core switching and routing sales (Infrastructure Platforms), which represent roughly 40% of total sales, have been on the decline. Cisco has been moving more into software and services, but hardware remains a big piece.
  • Cisco is a particularly important tech name to watch with earnings. Because it's so large and touches so many areas, it's a great barometer to get a general sense for enterprise sending levels on IT. It's also the first big tech name to report that includes the month of January, so we should get a better sense of how briskly enterprises are spending this winter season with COVID cases rising again.
  • Cisco has been active on the M&A front, announcing recent deals to acquire Acacia Communications (ACIA) for $4.5 bln and IMImobile for $730 mln. Acacia makes optical interconnect products that are used by cloud infrastructure operators, with a focus on embedded and pluggable modules. Pluggable modules is a high growth area and it's still in the early stages. The industry is transitioning from chassis-based systems to pluggable technology to simplify operations.
  • Finally, in terms of what to expect, Cisco has not missed on EPS in the past five years, so it's pretty reliable. Of note, the beats have been getting larger since the pandemic again, in the $0.06-0.08 range, following a series of smaller $0.01-0.03 beats. (PVIEW)
